Description: Terrible Arkansas Politics in Office, Racism everywhere
Pros: Lots of nice people who will verbally acknowledge your work (you will never be compensated for it though!) There are also really skillful people who tried to get into tech but couldn't due to visa issues, so culture is a mixed bag.
Cons: You will find yourself working with leadership who never had a college degree. If they have decided to pursue Walmart's college program, then they will only focus on class and not do any work. Saw my leader's calendar on a shared zoom call screen and everything scheduled was college courses and homework time.Pay is terrible, compensation isn't fair. They will find any reason to discriminate to drag your pay grade down. In my case, I have been out of university for 10 years and they still chose to give me a X2 grade because I Look Young and that will affect my relationships and prevent me from leading with authority. They also love to gossip so you can hear all about how they feel about you when you go sit with them back in the office.

Description: Very subjective but a decent place for the motivated
Pros: * You can stretch and take up more than you can chew. In the process, you get to work with some amazing talented folks, learn from them and grow in your career* Managers are usually nice and listen / act on your concerns. However, you may not see results because eventually US is calling the shots* Get to work on scale: If you haven't built anything for scale in your career yet, this might be the place to get a good start before moving on to bigger brands like PayPal, FAANG, etc. Not all products have to deal with scale, but there are enough.* Walmart in India is a good brand name to have on your resume. You will get calls from other tier 1 companies trying to poach you
Cons: * Lack of vision - products getting decommissioned and teams being asked to migrate in a very short time* Lack of travel - for a company who's entire footprint is North America, we don't see enough people doing short term travel, if any* Hiring sub-par devs in an effort to expand

Description: Thinking of interviewing/joining Walmart India ? Read on.
Pros: Compensation is pretty decent by India's standards. They will give you a good raise if you have done well in the interviews. That's it.
Cons: - You work during the day, and then during the night and you won't have a life.- Tech is dated, with no hurry to adopt new tech.- You will be busy, but not productive, you will attend pointless meeting for hours mostly during the end of the day because you know -  timezone.- All the good stuff gets filtered out by US teams, most India teams don't have project managers and program managers, so you do what you get.- The good managers don't stick for long, the ones who do, don't care much about you, but themselves.- A lot of politics - open politics.- Principal (and above) Engineers are not that good technically, they end up doing program management.** Did I know about all this before joining? **- To some extent yes, I knew of all the politics and bureaucracy but thought would have some work-life balance for a while (#slowpaced), but it's really a mess all day and late into evenings. No amount of hike can justify the low quality work being done. Everything told to you about employee friendly, atleast in India, is superficial.

Description: I like the work life Balance

I had a manager who made it really hard to convert from contractor to FTE though, but once I found a FTE role that I got an offer for, I am really happy with the role and the manager.Really miss my old team though. We were a small, tight knit team. Had a relationship outside of work too. But with the FTE role, I have more responsibilities and also the chance to try my hand at a different technology than the one I was hired for or what I've been doing.
Cons: Too many reorganizations going on. It worked out for me personally with the domain model, I don't know what its going to be like with the new Omni Channel model.I think moving all FEs into one place and distancing them from BEs doing Tech mod may not be a good move though.

Author Info: Verified User Current Employee  p*****  Technical Leader II - May 12, 2021

Description: So much has changed at Walmart this past year.
Pros: Never had an issue where anyone bothered me while on PTO. You get to work with some very kind and helpful people. Still uncertain how remote vs in-person work expectations will play out. I've never received a phone call from my boss after hours (6pm or later) but know for sure that others have. People are the best part of the job. Couldn't ask for a better culture, and work was much more enjoyable in-person than virtual. You will learn more here than most other retailers due to the size of our ecomm and B&M and your ability to take action in both businesses.
Cons: Low comp vs rest of industry. Walmart can be very bureaucratic, which probably surprises no one. Promotions come slowly, as Walmart has some very dated rules about time-in-chair requirements (three years) for Merchants at all levels. We re-organized in 2020 and have ave seen remarkably high attrition as the ecomm and store organizations were merged. Many ecomm people left rather than move to Bentonville, and our ability to manage that side of the business has suffered dramatically. Work loads have also increased dramatically and are part of the reason the high attrition continues. Our tech tools are buggy and inhibit ability to do our job. Management talks about being responsive to our needs but so far, very little at all has changed. Hardest part of the job is keeping up with all the things we are now responsible for, post-reorganization. We used to have tema of 8-9 managing ecomm, and 1-2 managing B&M. No we have 2-5 managing both. Doesn't make sense.

Description: Work in application support (CSII) at Walmart
Pros: Work was good when we had vendor partners. We were able to focus on fixing and improving our apps while coming up with new solutions. However, post Suresh Kumar (our new CTO for the last year), life has changed drastically where we are now providing level 1 support to our applications which are running on EOL hardware. No pros at all if working in operations. I am a software engineer 3 with master's degree doing night shifts and providing level 1 support to apps that do not belong to my skillset.
Cons: MICRO MANAGED, STRESSED AND UNDER APPRECIATED. these are the three words to describe the work in our area (CSII - Core Services - Item and Inventory). We are forced to work on applications which are not part of our skillset. I am supporting mainframe apps and my skillset is front end and java. I am expected to pull a rabbit out of my a*s every day. Despite doing all the bloody work, people in my team are getting fired and I get communication that I need to deliver more. Extremely stressful and underappreciated.Skip this area if you have other options.

Author Info: Verified User Current Employee  h****  Staff Software Development Engineer - Feb 14, 2021

Description: One of the nicest places to work in bangalore
Pros: Offers great work life balance, flexibility to choose your own timings etc based on the  team you are part of.Awesome colleagues and so far have seen an open and accomodative culture across geographies.Benefits and compensation are great and they do have decent annual hikes. Ample opportunity to have your input inserted in the roadmap if found good . Oppurtunity to pick up a lot great technologies as they are going through a tech modernization bid. Additionally there is no role/level based discrimination and they are quick to reward (mostly in cash) as well as provide relevant feedback atleast in my team.this last bit is probably purely based on your manager & the org leads and mine so far seems great.
Cons: It was rather confusing last year with regards to delivery expectation etc owing to idc being newly setup for some of our teams ..tooling work was largely adhoc in nature with bulk of them clustered towards the latter half of the year owing  to walmart ecom scale related concerns mostly being holiday centric . This pointed to not having a defined roadmap early on. On the positive side, they do take aes survey results very seriously atleast in my organization and are open to feed back . This year so far has been great especially since they revamped how we plan for the year ahead and has come up with a defined roadmap.

Author Info: Verified User Current Employee  L*****  Human Resources Senior Manager - Jul 3, 2020

Description: Not bad, very friendly and socially aware, hidden politics, many difficulties managing managers
Pros: 1. Very friendly and caring feel to it for focus on ethics, social issues, family and personal needs2. Work-life balance wonderful when comparing as large non-tech companies. Managers genuinely care about your happiness, or project the care enough so that it doesn't matter if genuine is really it3. Job security is good, it seems when the time is to say you need to leave, you will know before, except for if ethical problems happen. Then you go today, not next year!4. Total compensation is good, but not amazing. I'm happy enough, some complain
Cons: 1. Managers are managers, means that they often do not know the special area. This works sometimes, other times not. This seems to maybe risking of having a culture of professional trust derived from comfortable personal relations rather than special merit, this seems for special roles, like for engineering, technical. It is not what I mean as favoritism, but equivalent in effects when happening2. Managing the manager very difficult seemingly, perhaps for reason above in #1?3. Similar as #2, big insulation from next level manager/s and beyond. I have not any ideas about what standing a manager in my line has with their manager. A lot of game of telephone?4. Continuing the themes, politics within area and across business are not transparent. Politics are expected at a company of the size, the valuation but politics remain hidden. Some may prefer things that way?5. Dead weight is celebrated for causes of diversity, disagreeable weight is cut for causes of a big happy family. It seems to easy to release very smart mildly aggressive 5-10 year staff, but no 20 year staff feeling pressures seemingly, especially meaning diversity groups in US. 6. Based in the southern United States. Work remotely after COVID, but hard to communicate well. Work at HQ and you're in an area not like other parts of the US. If you are from the Southern area then maybe this is Pro7. The company have expectation of living the company attitude, put on your happy face, assertiveness can easily take an appearance of aggression or politically incorrectness. This is specific to your personality, if it feels ok to lose an argument when right, then it won't be so bad for you.These cons, many are easy understandable. Because, risk aversion, for a very large company in the stock market is what is normal. So taking this to mind with a grain of salt!Long list of cons, but this job is for me for now and I don't feel upset at any peer, supervisor, subordinate, etc. Hard to get mad at this company.

Author Info: Verified User Current Employee  U*****  Planning Manager - May 21, 2020

Pros: People are goodюWork-life balance is good. Environment is not demanding and you can do all you need to show in half a day and spend rest of it doing whatever you want.
Cons: Universally poor project management. Requirements for year-long program can consist of 4 sentences and 2 pictures. Complex project planning is performed in confluence tables. It percolates down to developers and without clear requirements people start faking research activity. Then deadline happen and project get moved, repeat, and then it's cancelled.Segmentation. Teams are not aligned under common goal and schedule, making improvements to cross-system concerns is beyond impossible. In all-hands meetings management repeats mantra highly independent, tightly aligned teams but nobody dears to ask what does it mean.Result does not matter, show-off is the objective. In all activities, delivering result does not feel as the objective. Most of the time disussions is around how to present what the team did. This leads to oversaturation, hiding empty hands behind pathetic but sophisticated sounding terminology and all tricks to fake activity. It hurts morale of good engineers because fake masters are successful whereas skills and results will give you nothing.
